title: Palo Alto software company 'Grexit' opts for name change
text:

Wed, Sep 16, 2015, 08:21 BST - UK Markets close in 8 hrs 9 mins Palo Alto software company 'Grexit' opts for name change By Lauren Davidson | Telegraph â€“ 1 hour 51 minutes ago Print 
Following heightened concerns this summer that Greece and the eurozone could part ways, a Silicon Valley software firm is changing its name to Hiver 
An unlikely casualty of the Greek debt crisis is the Palo Alto-based software company that has decided to ditch its unfortunate name . 
GrexIt, a business tool for using Gmail, is rebranding as Hiver following "extraneous circumstances, totally out of our control". 
The term Grexit used to refer to the possibility of Greece's exit from the eurozone surged in popularity this summer as it seemed ever more likely that Greece and the single currency bloc could part ways. 
In a blog post seen by the Telegraph, the software solutions firm said its name, which was chosen in 2011 from the Latin word for crowd or flock, grex, had "seemed to be an excellent name" for a company that helped teams collaborate better on email. 
After CitiGroup analysts attached the phrase to the Greek crisis in 2012, the Silicon Valley company saw a bump in its web traffic and, along with it, an increase in its bounce rates, or visitors who leave the website immediately. 
"We learnt to live with it, and factored it into how we analysed our traffic," GrexIt said. "But nothing prepared us for what happened earlier this year." 
This summer, Greece defaulted on a debt repayment to the IMF and the public voted overwhelmingly against austerity bailout conditions , leading to heightened concerns that Greece would be expelled from the eurozone. 
GrexIt said this resulted in more confusion about what it does and created a negative connotation around its name . 
Despite persevering through the summer, the Indian start-up has taken the plunge and changed it name to Hiver, because "bees are awesome creatures" that represent "work ethic, organisation and efficiency". 
Here's hoping the bees crisis doesn't get any worse.
